Dear Ms. Harding:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Eligibility requirements.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504.
Section (1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
Description independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There is concern Youth A was placed inappropriately. Youth A
has complained about being at the facility, has mental health
issues and other youths have threatened her.
Investigation Interviews:
2

On 4/18/2024, I interviewed the Emergency Medical Technician
(EMT) by telephone. The EMT reported she did not know or
report anything about mental health issues, a safety plan or
suicidal behavior for Youth A. The EMT reported she was
concerned for Youth A’s safety, due to Youth A alleging another
youth at the facility had a knife, verbal threats a youth made while
the EMT was on the facility’s site about beating Youth A’s “ass”;
and how the staff onsite had behaved. The staff had not given her
names and reported not being able to intervene if Youth A was
attacked. The investigation related to these EMT concerns are
discussed in another allegation section of this report.
On 4/22/2024 I interviewed the Program Director (PD) by
telephone. Additionally, I spoke with her during my onsite facility
visit on 4/25/2024, and a follow-up telephone call on 5/21/2024.
The PD reported Youth A does have on going mental health
concerns; and Youth A receives weekly therapy through the
agency’s Therapist. The PD reported Youth A was placed in
Holy’s Cross’ Independent Living (IL) program because Youth A
met the agency’s criteria for placement. She reported they have
a team process for intake that includes, the agency’s foster care
worker, house manager, and supervisor all sitting in on a youth’s
interview for placement. They look at the youth’s behavior, mental
health diagnoses needs, and length of time since a youth’s last
episodes. They accept youths with mental health diagnoses, past
self-harming behavior, those on psychotic medications and/or with
past mental health hospitalizations. They use a three-tier eligibility
scaling system to aid them in admission determination; and make
their decisions case by case, based on the youth, all the
information available and services that can be provided to the
youth. The PD acknowledged Youth A has had some peer
interaction struggles which is a part off her past history, along with
self-harming and/or cutting behavior.
On 4/24/2024 I interviewed Youth A’s Therapist related to the
allegations by telephone. I had a follow up contact with the
Therapist via telephone on 5/22/2024. The Therapist reported
the agency determined as a team that Youth A was appropriate
for the agency’s IL program. He reported the appropriateness of
Youth A for the program was determined by way of review of
Youth A’s referral, and past documented history. He reported
there was nothing seen in Youth A’s history that caused her not to
be accepted for placement. He reported Youth A has been in the
program for about six months now, and although Youth A has had
issues with her peers, is not always sincere in her statements; and
struggles to follow her treatment plan, this placement remains an
3

appropriate one for her. He reported meeting with Youth A weekly
for therapy. He reported if this placement was not appropriate they
would request Youth A’s replacement.
The Therapist reported he has completed three safety plans with
Youth A around her behaviors. The last one was on 4/18/2024
around physical aggression with peers. Two others were
completed on 3/22/2024, and 2/15/2024 for risky behavior on her
cell phone, and electronic media; related to engaging in
pornography/ inappropriate social media posting of her photos,
respectively. He reported if any self-harming or cutting had been
known or reported to him, he would have safety planned with
Youth A around that behavior. He would have also completed a
suicide assessment and determine if resources were needed.
On 4/25/2024 I interviewed the House Manager onsite at the IL
home. The House Manager reported Youth A interviewed well at
intake. She concurred with the PD and Therapist that Youth A met
criteria for the program. She confirmed other staff persons’
reporting of Youth A having some inappropriate behaviors around
cell phone use and peer interaction. She indicated a current issue
of trying to get Youth A to commit to taking her medications; but
she does not feel Youth A is a danger to herself. She reported,
Youth A likes to play games and instigates social problems.
On 5/6/2024 I interviewed Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW)
by telephone. I had a follow-up telephone interview with her on
5/25/2024. The FCW reported assignment to Youth A’s case when
the youth was placed at the agency’s IL home. The FCW advised
Youth A was accepted into the program in February 2024; and the
final decision for a youth ‘s placement into the program is by the
administrator. The FCW reported any concerns she has around
Youth A’s mental health has centered on Youth A’s need for more
structure due to the youth’s lack of maturity; and Youth A’s
refusals to take her medication; and to go to medical
appointments. The latter of which the FCW reported they continue
to address with Youth A; and have been discussing with the
department via family team meetings (FTM).
On 4/25/2024 I interviewed Youth A onsite at the IL home. She
reported being in this IL program since February 2024. She
reported the program is meeting her needs, and that she feels
safe here. She reported there is no other place for her to go, but
that does not matter because in two months, when she turns 18,
she is leaving.
4

Document Review
Youth A’s case record which showed:
• She was placed at Holy Cross’s IL- Plus program on
2/5/2024.
• She is a temporary Court Ward.
• She has had both foster home and child caring institution
placements, the last of which was Wedgewood Christian
services.
Holy Cross IL-Plus Program Referral form dated 1/2/2024
completed by Youth A’s POS worker, which indicated:
• Youth A’s diagnosis of major depressive disorder
generalized anxiety disorder, attention deficit hyperactive
disorder and unspecified mood disorder. She had past
experimentation with marijuana and alcohol, and meth
once.
• Medications as Buspirone, Vyvanse, Venlafaxine,
Lamotrigine, Prazosin, and these medications have been
administered by staff over the last nine months.
• Youth A does well with change if she is aware of it
beforehand.
• MDHHS has spent a lot of time talking with her about ILP
and Youth A is looking forward to the change.
Youth A’s Initial Service Plan (1/10/2023-2/8/2023) and last
Updated Service plan (8/8/23-11/3/2023) prior to her Holy Cross
IL placement which showed:
• Youth A had past foster home and child caring institution
placements.
• Youth A had past peer aggressive behaviors, and self-
harming behaviors, inclusive of cutting of her arms.
Incident Reports from Youth A’s prior Wedgwood Christian
Service’s placement dating back from 5/30/2023 to 1/2/2024
which showed:
• An incident of Youth A joking around with a peer and falling
on a chair and reporting pain to her thigh/glute area.
• Peer conflicts, physical aggressions; and physical
altercations and assaults.
• Frustrations, tensions for Youth A of: Youth A cutting the
top of her right and left thigh on 6/10/23. The cuts were
superficial with slight bleeding. Youth A punching a white
board on 7/20/2023, due to being upset. Youth A using
the arm from her sunglasses to create several superficial
cuts on her forearm on 8/1/2023. Youth A using sharp
pieces of sunglasses to cut her left forearms and upper
5

right leg on 8/16/2023. Youth A threatening to self-harm on
other occasions; and Youth A having cuts to both arms and
both forelegs on 10/29/2023 from glass fragments from her
watch.
Holy Cross Program statement & IL-Plus Eligibility Scaling which
showed:
• The youth and referring worker participated in an interview
to determine self-care potential and determine placement
acceptance or denial.
• At the time of admission, Youth A met the agency’s
placement criteria.
• Holy Cross IL Safety plans dated 2/15/2024, 3/22/2024,
4/18/2024 as described by the Therapist showing the
agency trying to work with Youth A around her mental
health and peer aggressions, interpersonal interactions,
and anxiety and frustrations.
Conclusion The agency is found in compliance with this rule as per staff and
documents reviewed, it showed Youth A met the agency’s
placement criteria at the time of placement; and per indication by
referral information from the MDHHS referring worker, she was
looking forward to the IL placement at that time.
Rule Code Supervision.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12505.
Section (1) An agency shall provide supervision for a youth in independent
Description living consistent with the youth's need for supervision, as required
by R 400.12504(2)(e).
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation (1) During a visit by EMS (Emergency Medical Services) to Youth
A’s group home on 4/16/2024 to transport her to the hospital for
reported back pain, three girls from the home threatened to beat
up Youth A if she came back in the house. The staff on duty did
not believe the girls were actually going to beat-up Youth A. The
staff person reported she would not be able to intervene physically
if the girls did so. She would contact 911. Youth A told EMS, the
girls in the home have been threatening her.
(2) During the EMS visit to the group home on 4/16/2024 Youth A
reported she had been cutting herself to deal with the stress of
moving into the group home where she has lived since February
2024.
6

Investigation
Allegation (1)
Interviews:
On 4/18/2024, I interviewed the Emergency Medical Technician
(EMT) by telephone. The EMT reported during an emergency run
to the facility where Youth A resides, Youth A reported youths
were threatening her. The EMT said while she was on the scene
with the Mt. Morris police, three youths came out to the porch area
and threatened Youth A. One of the youth told Youth A if she
came back inside, they would beat her “ass”. The police told the
youths to go back inside. There was one staff with the youths,
and this staff person refused to give her name; and did not seem
to be concerned about the behaviors of the other youths toward
Youth A. The staff person said she did not believe the youth(s)
would beat up Youth A, but if they tried, she could not intervene;
that she was pregnant, and she would have to call 911. The staff
also did not seem to know about Youth A’s parent/guardian
information so as to who could give consent for EMS to transport
Youth A. Additionally, the staff person said she could not leave to
accompany Youth A to the hospital due to there being eight
youths in the home and she was the only staff. The EMT reported
she was concerned for Youth A’s safety due to Youth A alleging a
youth at the facility had a knife, the verbal threat by the other
youth, the staff’s behavior related to that threat; and the police
indicating there had been a number of prior complaints to this
facility which they thought should be closed.
On 4/22/2024 I interviewed the PD by telephone; and spoke with
her onsite on 4/25/2024. She was not onsite at the time of the
EMS visit. She was not sure who made the call to EMS but the
Youth Worker (YW) 1 was the afternoon staff onsite at the time of
the incident. The PD reported the YW 1 is pregnant but that does
not prohibit YW 1 from intervening in youth conflicts, by giving
directions to the youths as warranted to deescalate a situation.
The PD reported YW 1 deals with each situation seriously and
utilizes the team when needed by making contacts with them and
having them give input and assistance as able.
The PD reported the alleged incident of Youth A’s peer allegedly
threatening her was likely connected to a situation pertaining to a
male youth in another of the agency’s IL programs. She reported
Youth A had alleged to her earlier in the day on 4/16/2024 that
Youth E threatened her. Reportedly Youth A and Youth E met at
an agency holiday event; and their relationship ended in or around
April 2024. According to Youth A, Youth E told Youth A if she was
pregnant, he would kill her. Due to that alleged threat, the PD
7

reported the agency assisted Youth A with a police report on
4/16/2024. Youth A told the other youth in the house she filed the
police report against Youth E; and one or more of the youths were
upset with Youth A about this, due to their friendship with Youth E.
Words were exchanged between Youth A and one or more of the
other youths. YW 1 sent a message to the team about the
incident; and the police were also called. The PD reported the
incident was likely still spilling over when the police and EMS
came on the scene related to the EMS call. She denied Youth A
reporting anything about a knife, or anyone having a knife. She
reported YW 2 was also coming onsite to relieve YW 1. She
denied a lack of supervision by staff.
On 4/24/2024 I interviewed Youth A’s Therapist by telephone
related to the allegations. He was not onsite at the time of this
incident; nor did he receive information that three youths had
threatened to beat up Youth A. He reported what he knew was
secondhand. He reported there was one youth, Youth A had an
issue with, which was reportedly over a cell phone loan, and
something (the specifics unknown) to do with a male youth; and
Youth A may have misconstrued what she had heard. It was
reported to him that Youth B, not three youths, had threatened
Youth A. He reported Youth A reported having a verbal
disagreement with the youth, but she did not report that youth’s
name at the time or tell him what the verbal argument was about.
He said the same youth that Youth A was complaining about is the
one she is hanging out with now. He reported it is a behavior
pattern of Youth A’s to not be sincere in her statements about
issues. That one-minute Youth A will complain about her peers,
and in the next she is going to activities with those peers. The
Therapist reported he believes Youth A is safe in this placement
with her peers. He did not report any concerns about her
supervision.
On 4/25/2024 while onsite at the IL home, I interviewed the House
Manager, Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, YW 1 and YW 2
about the allegations. Youth B refused to speak with me.
The House Manager reported there had been a lot going on that
day due to the youth gossiping; and Youth A reportedly getting on
the phone and telling some untruths. The House Manager said
tensions were high prior to the police arriving the second time.
She said she made the first police call related to allegations Youth
A reported to the PD related to Youth E, as described earlier in
this report by the PD. She reported Youth B who has always been
close to Youth A, and concerned for Youth A’s well-being was
8

upset by what Youth A reported about Youth E. That Youth B’s
boyfriend and Youth E are all friends. Youth B and Youth A had
words about this situation. She said Youth B can be verbally
“vulgar “, curse, and Youth B was reportedly still upset and argued
at Youth A when the police arrived.
The House Manager reported she was not onsite when the police
arrived the second time, but what was reported to her was Youth
B made the verbal threat to beat up Youth A, and the other youth
were trying to get Youth B to come back to her room. As to YW 1
saying to EMS that YW 1 did not believe the youth would attack
Youth A, the House Manager reported this was likely due to the
fact that YW 1 knows Youth B’s tendency to be very “verbal and
vulgar”; and Youth B has never acted on her threats. The House
Manager reported Youth A is normally the instigator of trouble and
when caught, Youth A tries to redirect the situation to something
or someone else. The House Manager reported the staff try to
redirect Youth A’s inappropriate actions, as they do with other
youths. She reported staff address youths’ conflicts and threats of
fights by trying to get the less aggressor of the youths to go to
their room; or having both youths to go to their room to calm
down, so staff can talk with them.
Youth A reported while the police and EMS were onsite at the IL
home on 4/16/2024 Youth B came to the door and told her “I’m
beating your ass”. There were three youths there but only Youth
B threatened her. The others, whom she would not name said,
“come inside and see”. Youth A stated Youth B said what Youth B
said because Youth B wanted to fight her. Youth A denied
knowing why Youth B wanted to fight her. She said the youths
were being “messy”; but she would not explain what that meant.
She would not report Youth B or anyone having a knife, she said
she just wants this thing dropped. That she and Youth B, and the
other youths talked, and they are friends. She admitted staff
intervene when any of the youths try to fight. She said the staff
can’t touch them to do this, but they use de-escalation or call 911.
She reported feeling safe in this placement.
Youth C reported they play and joke around with each other a lot.
Youth C did not disclose any information about what may have
happened between the youth on 4/16/2024, when the police and
EMS had come to the facility; she said she had to leave. She
reported they know they are not to fight, but if they get into any
kind of altercation, staff will intervene and tell them to stop. She
reported feeling safe in this IL home.
9

Youth D reported staff tend to not let youth arguments escalate.
Staff will try to deescalate the issue, suggest space between them
by telling the youths involved to go to their room. Staff will also
call the police. Youth D was not aware of any youth fights since
her placement in the home two weeks ago. She admitted that on
4/16/2024 there were youths arguing and one youth had
threatened to beat up Youth A. She reported what happened was
not out of the normal, that youths get angry, argue, threaten to
fight and then are ok with one another. She indicated this is what
happened with Youth A. Youth D was not aware of anyone having
a knife. She said Youth A came from the hospital and everything
was okay again with her and the other youths. Everyone was
okay with one another. Youth D reported feeling safe in this IL
home.
YW 2 reported, she was not onsite when EMS and the police
arrived onsite on 4/16/2024. She reported there was some type
of incident between Youth A and Youth B over a phone Youth B
loaned to Youth A; and Youth B wanting it back. She did not
report any direct information about any youths threatening Youth
A. She acknowledged what others had related to what staff do
when youths argue or want to fight. They try to calm the situation
down, suggest youths separate; and if necessary call 911.
YW 1 reported, she was the staff on shift on 4/16/2024 when the
alleged incident occurred. She reported the police arrived and
reported someone called EMS, who were on the way. She denied
not allowing Youth A to speak with the official privately; or to ever
trying to talk over Youth A. She denied ever seeing three youths
outside or anyone other than Youth B threatening Youth A. She
said she was back and forth talking with the officer and checking
on the youths. She admitted there was a time that she heard
Youth B yell something to the effect “I will beat your ass” and the
police told Youth B to go back inside, but she was not sure if
Youth B was actually outside or was just at the door. She said the
other two youths, were telling Youth B to stop and come in. YW 1
said she thought the situation with Youth A and Youth B which
had occurred long before the police arrived had calmed down and
was over. The arguing had stopped, and Youth A was in her room.
YW1 admitted she told the EMT something to the effect that she
did not believe Youth B would follow up on her threat to harm
Youth A. She reported saying this because Youth B “was talking
junk”, which is what Youth B does; but also, because Youth B and
Youth A are close/always together; and Youth B does not fight.
She was surprised the two had argued. She also admitted to
10

telling the EMT she was pregnant; and if a fight were to break out
she could not get between the youths to break them up. YW1
reported that is also true if she was not pregnant. She reported
she would try to talk with the youths to encourage them to stop;
and if they would not comply and if she could not deescalate the
situation, she would call the police.
On 5/6/2024 I interviewed Youth A’s FCW about the allegations by
telephone. She was not onsite at the time of the alleged incident.
She reported Youth A told her later, that a youth had threatened to
beat her up, but Youth A had not given her any details. Youth A
has not reported any concerns about that peer since; and the two
youths are friend again.
It is noted that neither of the staff interviewed reported anything
about Youth A mentioning to either of them information about a
knife.
Allegation (2)
Interviews
On 4/18/2024, I interviewed the EMT by telephone. The EMT
reported during an emergency run to the facility where Youth A
resides, Youth A reported concerns about being at the facility.
Youth A reported moving to the facility in February 2024; and that
she had cut herself to deal with the stress of moving. Youth A
also reported youths were threatening to beat her up (as
examined earlier in this report). Youth A also showed the EMT a
cut mark on her left arm. Youth A did not say when or how she
had cut her arm. The EMT did not report the size of the mark or
how old it appeared. The EMT reported she did not know or report
anything about a safety plan or suicidal behavior for Youth A. The
EMT reported she was concerned for Youth A’s safety. She
reported the staff had not given her name and did not have
information related to the youth and consent for transport. The
EMT reported getting supervisory approval to transport the youth.
On 4/22/2024 I interviewed the PD by telephone related to the
allegations and had a follow up telephone conversation with her
related to this allegation on 5/21/2024.
The PD acknowledged Youth A has had some peer interaction
struggles which is a part off her past history as is self-harming or
cutting behavior. The PD reported no knowledge of the latter
behavior being reported for Youth A since Youth A’s February
2024 placement in the program. She reported if cutting behavior
11

had occurred, staff would have safety planned with Youth A
around it.
The PD reported there had not been an issue with EMS being
unable to transport Youth A, or the agency staff not having
information related to the youth/the agency right’s to provide care
onsite. She reported the agency has a binder with consent
information and YW 1 showed that to EMS and tried to explain
things, but EMS was not accepting of that.
On 4/24/2024 I interviewed Youth A’s Therapist related to the
allegations. I had a follow up contact with him by telephone on
5/21/2024. He reported, self-harming may have been a part of
Youth A’s past history, but he could not recall from Youth A’s
referral data the last time such behavior was reported as having
occurred. He reported Youth A has not displayed such behavior
since her placement in the IL home. He denied an awareness of
Youth A cutting herself, and reported Youth A never reported she
was cutting herself due to stress. Nor had Youth A showed him a
cut or mark on her arm that she allegedly inflicted on herself. He
said Youth A has a history of reporting things that are not true,
especially if it gets her attention or a rise from the person, she is
reporting the matter to. He reported when things Youth A alleges
are explored, it usually shows inconsistences; and Youth A
changes her story. He reported completing three separate safety
plans with Youth A around her behaviors of peer encounters and
aggression, and inappropriate social interactions and or posting
on her cell phone and social media (all as reported and described
earlier in this report). He reported if self-harming or cutting
behavior had been known or reported to him, he would have
completed a safety plan with Youth A around this behavior. He
would have also completed a suicide assessment and or sought
other resources if warranted.
On 5/6/2024 I interviewed Youth A’s FCW by telephone. I had a
follow-up telephone interview with her on 5/22/2024; and email
communication from her on 6/4/2024. The FCW reported any
concern she has around Youth A’s mental health were as reported
earlier in this reported related to Youth A’s immaturity, medication
and medical appointment refusal. She denied any direct
knowledge of Youth A self-harming related to stress. As to
whether Youth A had any cutting behaviors, the FCW reported
about one week after Youth A had gone to the hospital on
4/16/2024, Youth A told her, she had cut her arm; and Youth A
showed her what appeared to be an old scratch mark on Youth
A’s arm. The FCW could not recall which arm. The FCW said had
12

she seen the mark any other time, she would not have thought
anything about it. The FCW also acknowledged cutting as a past
behavior for Youth A; and stated this alleged reporting of such
behavior by Youth A was the first since Youth A’s placement at
this IL home. The FCW did not recall asking Youth A for details
about the mark/what Youth A alleged. At that time, she did not
ask Youth A whether Youth A cut her arm on purpose,
accidentally, or when the alleged cut occurred. She did not share
this information with the Therapist; she stated she forgot. Nor did
she write the incident up via a case note or complete a safety
plan. She reported not writing it because she has so many
contacts with the youths in a day (given they are in the same
building) she does not always document all interactions.
The FCW said she followed up with Youth A a couple of times
after Youth A showed her the mark to see if Youth A was ok. The
contacts were one to two days after Youth A’s reporting and Youth
A reported she was fine. The FCW could not recall if she
documented the follow up contacts. She did not report any
concerns for Youth A’s supervision.
It is noteworthy the Therapist and FCW followed up with Youth A
following my last telephone conservation with them and completed
a safety plan with Youth A around any potential self-harming/
cutting behavior. A copy of this safety plan was provided to me
and is dated 5/22/2024.
On 4/25/2024 I interviewed Youth A onsite at the IL home. She
did not report cutting herself or telling anyone she had. As
mentioned earlier in this report, Youth A reported the program is
meeting her needs, that she feels safe here; and there being no
other place for her to go. Additionally, that she intends to leave the
program once she turns 18.
On 4/25/2024 I interviewed YW 1 about the allegations onsite. I
had a follow-up telephone interview with her about this allegation
on 5/22/2024. YW 1 denied Youth A ever mentioning anything to
her about cutting herself, prior to Youth A’s ER visit or since then.
YW 1 reported during the ER visit Youth A never mentioned
cutting herself. Youth A never talked about this to the doctor. The
only thing Youth A talked about was pain on her side. YW 1
recalled Youth A wearing long sleeves that day, and she did not

Analysis Allegation 1
The agency is in compliance with rule. A staff was present with
Youth A and the other youths when EMS and the police arrived.
The staff on site had been addressing a conflict between Youth A
14

and Youth B prior. Sometime during or after that incident, Youth A
called EMS and complained about pain in her side.
Allegation 2
The agency is in violation of the rule. The PD, and Therapist both
reported Youth A had a history of self-harming by way of cutting,
and they were not aware of such behavior or reporting of such
behavior by Youth A since Youth A’s February 2024 placement
into the program. Conversely, the FCW who also acknowledged
an awareness of Youth A’s past history of self-harming by cutting,
reported a week or so after 4/16/2024 Youth A disclosed she had
cut herself. The FCW reported the cut Youth A showed her was
an old scratch mark; and she did not explore the matter further
with Youth A at that time. The FCW seemingly concluded since
Youth A had a habit of reporting false information, that was the
case in this incident. The FCW did not document this alleged
reporting by Youth A or report the matter to Youth A’s therapist so
that it could be explored further and that a safety plan could be
enacted.
Given Youth A’s past history of self-harming by cutting at the point
that Youth A alleged that act to the FCW, safety planning was
warranted so as to ensure for Youth A supervision around this
issue. That did not occur at that time.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
